history.content:
Almost all of the requirements can be overcome with special petitions or enough support from the responsible professors. They are chiller than you think about most of them. Also you'll want to look at your technical GPA as well. I'm not 100% sure about this one specifically though. 

That being said, 61b is one of the most competitive lower division courses to TA for, especially if Hug is teaching. There will already be lots of other qualified applicants who will have higher GPA's and also will not require such special support. So regardless of whether it is a solid or recommended requirement, it will be quite an uphill battle unless you have a really special ace up your sleeve. 

I think I saw one TA overcome the GPA requirement but he had a good relationship with the professor teaching and also it was for an upper-division course, which has more informal hiring. Lower division hiring is a factory process. 

Source: am head TA for a CS course.

children.subject: It can be but again, there are many people who got As and who have a higher cum gpa that are more likely to be selected since 61b is one of the most competitive course to TA for.
likely controversial opinion: don’t TA for a class you got lower than an A- in. I don’t think you have a good enough understanding of the material to be teaching it.
I wouldn't want my TA to have gotten lower than an A-

It's theoretically possible but practically even more unlikely. At least with a low overall GPA you could reason "maybe this guy is really super duper good at X for which he wants to TA for, but not Y and Z" (which happens). A low grade in the course you want to TA for sends the wrong signal. I know professors who will refuse to hire even A-'s. For some lower divs I know people who got A+'s who got rejected. 

Even getting an A or even A+ is no guarantee you understand the material to the depth required to truly teach it, especially without the context that grad students and professors have. 

Source: Am the head TA from the student response.
Honestly most of the TAs I have had weren't that great and I am assuming they all got at least an A. If I had a TA that got lower I would not trust them to convey information properly.
Which classes? In my experience I had to “try” 2-3 different TA’s before finding one that fit my learning style; maybe try this next semester.

Maybe. I always went to my assigned discussion TA and never had the chance to experiment around as I found there to not be enough time in my schedule to accomodate for different discussion sections and ,well, lack of caring enough to attend discussion (which is very bad lol). I will def try this this upcoming semester.
Thanks! Is the A- rule just as flexible? I got a B+ as opposed to an A- in another class I was considering TAing for.

history.content:
Hi,
I was interested in becoming a TA for CS61B, but while I was looking over the requirements I noticed that people applying needed to have a cumulative GPA of 3.0. I wanted to know if this was a solid requirement or is it just recommended? If my cumulative GPA is around a 2.5 will I have to bring it up to a 3.0 just to be a TA?
history.subject: Becoming a TA
